user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.2 is: A project shall not contain dead code.
Any operation that is executed but whose removal would not affect program behaviour constitutes dead code. Notes:
1. The behaviour of an embedded sytem is often determined not just by the nature of its actions, but also by the time at which they occur.
2. unreachable code is not dead code, as it cannot be executed.
3.Initialization is not the same as an assignment operation and is therfore not a candidate for dead code.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of process_param__shared:
```c
static enum PerfRepl_param_result
process_param__shared (const char *param_name)
{
  if (tool_params.single)
  {
    fprintf (stderr, "Parameter '%s' cannot be used together "
             "with '-I' or '--single'.\n", param_name);
    return PERF_RPL_PARAM_ERROR;
  }
  if (tool_params.unique)
  {
    fprintf (stderr, "Parameter '%s' cannot be used together "
             "with '-U' or '--unique'.\n", param_name);
    return PERF_RPL_PARAM_ERROR;
  }
  tool_params.shared = ! 0;
  return '-' == param_name[1] ?
         PERF_RPL_PARAM_FULL_STR :PERF_RPL_PARAM_ONE_CHAR;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I did not mark the if(...) bodies (fprintf(...) / return PERF_RPL_PARAM_ERROR;) as suspicious for dead code because they have observable side-effects (diagnostic output and an early return). Removal of those statements would change program behaviour unless it is proven across the whole project that the corresponding condition can never be true; unreachable code (never executed) is not classified as dead code per the rule notes. The conditional checks (if (tool_params.single) / if (tool_params.unique)) themselves are normal control-flow constructs; whether their bodies are executed (and thus whether those bodies are dead) requires whole-project analysis of how those flags are set. Likewise the function signature and the surrounding structure are unaffected by Rule 2.2 in this context. Therefore only the assignment to tool_params.shared and the final ternary return are reported as suspicious: the assignment could be a no-op if the field is never read elsewhere, and the ternary return may contain a branch that never affects behavior (e.g. if both enum values are identical or the checked character never differs) — both require project-wide inspection to confirm whether they constitute dead code.
